questions.question: In the outpatient department, a female patient presents with arthritis that symmetrically affects multiple joints, including the wrists, hands, and feet. The patient reports morning stiffness lasting for more than 1 hour, and examination reveals swollen and tender joints.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Rheumatoid arthritis Explanation: A female patient with symmetrical involvement of joints with morning stiffness is suggestive of Rheumatoid arthritis. Joint involvement in Arthritic diseases: Disease Joint involved & characteristics Joint spared Osteoarthritis (Option C) Proximal and Distal interphalangeal joints (PIP and DIP), 1st Carpometacarpal joint, Hip and knee Asymmetrical involvement Wrist and Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A) Metacarpophalangeal joint (MCP) - most commonly involved Symmetrical involvement seen Morning stiffness present Distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) and 1st carpometacarpal (CMP) joint Psoriatic arthritis (Option B) Proximal and Distal interphalangeal joints (PIP and DIP) Pencil-in-cup, telescoping of digits, arthritis mutilans Skin and nail involvement + Ray pattern distribution of joints seen Gout (Option D): First metatarsophalangeal joint is first affected followed by ankle, knee, elbow and wrist joints. Acute gout attacks are characterized by painful swollen joints with fever and malaise. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Pages 67,78,87,88,91,92.

questions.question: An elderly patient with the presented deformity was brought to the outpatient department (OPD). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: hand with ulnar deviation of the fingers, which is a classic finding in rheumatoid arthritis (RA). It is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the joints. It is characterized by synovial membrane inflammation, which lines the joint space, leading to progressive cartilage and bone destruction. Clinical features of Rheumatoid arthritis: Symmetrical polyarthritis, polysynovitis with soft-tissue swelling- Pain and morning stiffness in multiple joints usually lasting more than 30 minutes. Generalized myopathy or neuropathy, tiredness, and loss of weight. As the disease progresses, joint deformity, joint instability, and tendon rupture. Joints affected Common MP joints of the hand PIP joints of fingers Wrists, knees, elbows, ankles Less common Hip joint Temporo-mandibular joint Spares sacroiliac joint and distal inter phalangeal joints. Deformities in Rheumatoid arthritis Hand Ulnar deviation of the hand Swan neck deformity Boutonniere deformity Elbow: Flexion deformity Knee Valgus deformity Ankle: Equinus deformity Foot Hallux valgus Hammer toe Extra-articular manifestations of Rheumatoid arthritis: Vasculitis Rheumatoid nodules- Subcutaneous, over bony prominences, in the synovium, on tendons, in the sclera, and the viscera. Size is increased by methotrexate. Serositis Felty's syndrome: Severe splenomegaly + neutropenia + RA. (Option A) Rickets (Option A) is a condition that results from the deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphorus, leading to poor bone mineralization. It commonly presents with bowing of the legs, delayed growth, and softening of the skull bones. Osteomalacia (Option B) is a condition that results from the deficiency of vitamin D or calcium, leading to the softening of bones, most commonly seen in adults . It commonly presents with bone pain, muscle weakness, and fractures. Osteoarthritis (Option C) is a degenerative joint disease that primarily affects the articular cartilage. It commonly presents with joint pain, stiffness, and limited range of motion.

questions.question: A 72-year-old man came with complaints of unilateral knee pain. X-ray examination showed reduced joint space. Histopathological examination of the affected joint is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Osteoarthritis Explanation: In histopathology, there is loss of Articular cartilage. Reduced joint space on X-ray and unilateral knee pain is highly suggestive of osteoarthritis. The clinical manifestations and X-ray showing joint space narrowing, irregular joint surface, subchondral sclerosis, and osteophyte formation are consistent with a diagnosis of Osteoarthritis. DMARDs target immune and inflammatory pathways to slow disease progression in conditions like Rheumatoid arthritis and are not used in osteoarthritis. X-ray features seen in Osteoarthritis: Radiological features Pathology Joint space narrowing Focal areas of loss of articular cartilage Osteophytes Bone growth at the joint margins Sclerosis of subchondral bone Sclerosis of underlying bone Bone cysts Cyst formation in underlying bone Bone attrition Loss of bone Apparent effusions Varying degrees of synovial inflammation Not visible on radiographs Fibrosis and thickening of the joint capsule Treatment: Supportive therapy: Weight reduction Stress management Local heat provides relief of pain and stiffness Quadriceps strengthening exercises - improve stability of the knee joint No unnecessary knee movements. Medical treatment: Paracetamol Topical NSAIDs Intra-articular injections: Local anesthetic Corticosteroid Hyaluronic acid Surgical treatment: Osteotomy Joint replacement (Partial or total) - in advanced disease stages Arthroscopic procedures - minimally invasive procedures.

questions.question: What is the current stage of the disease in a patient who presents with hip pain and true shortening of the limb, and is diagnosed with tuberculosis of the hip?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Stage of advanced arthritis Explanation: Presence of hip pain and true shortening of the limb is suggestive of Stage-III TB hip , known as Stage of advanced arthritis . Babulkar and Pandey Clinico-Radiological Classification of TB Hip stages: Stage Clinical Findings X-ray findings Stage I: Synovitis (Option A) Irritable hip Increased FABER (Flexion, Abduction, External Rotation) Apparent lengthening due to FABER (Position of ease due to synovitis) Terminal movements are restricted by 25% Normal or haziness of the articular margins Stage II: Early Arthritis (Option B) Early joint pain, stiffness Increased FADIR (Flexion, Adduction, Internal Rotation) Apparent shortening due to FADIR Gluteal and Quadriceps muscle wasting ROM restricted by 50% Osteopenia and narrowing of joint space Stage III: Late Arthritis (Option C) Marked FADIR True shortening Gross restriction of movements (usually >50%) Marked subchondral erosion and destruction Stage IV: Pathological Dislocation /severe arthritis (Option D) Marked FADIR Gross shortening Severe destruction and loss of joint space " Wandering/traveling Acetabulum ": Pathological dislocation/subluxation due to gross destruction of the femoral head or the superior acetabular margin. End stage of TB hip/arthritis: Fibrous ankylosis End stage of TB spine: Bony ankylosis Reference: Maheshwari’s Essential Orthopaedics 6th Edition pages 196,197

questions.question: A 67-year-old diabetic patient presented with swelling around the knee, restriction of movement and minimal or no pain. The x-ray of the knee is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Charcot arthropathy Explanation: Known diabetic with arthritic presentation and x-ray showing destruction of lateral femoral condyle is more likely to be Charcot’s arthropathy . Charcot Joints (Neuropathic joint): Description: Progressive, degenerative & destructive joint disorder due to abnormal pain sensation & proprioception Joints involved: Foot and ankle Shoulder Elbow Knee Hand Most Common Joint Involved: Foot - Tarsometatarsal joint > Metatarsophalangeal joint Etiology: Cause Mechanism Common Joint Involved Diabetes mellitus (Most common cause) (Option C) Peripheral neuropathy leads to altered pain sensation and proprioception Foot Syphilis (Tabes dorsalis) Neurological deficits affecting joint function Knee Syringomyelia Dilatation of the spinal cord; may lead to syringobulbia (if it extends to the Brainstem) Shoulder Leprosy Neuropathy leading to loss of sensation Hand and Foot Meningomyelocele Neurological deficits impacting joint function Variable, but often lower limbs X-ray: Rapid destruction of articular surfaces + involvement of multiple small joints Incorrect Options: Rheumatoid Arthropathy (RA) (Option A): In the case of rheumatoid arthropathy bone softening and soft tissue changes are seen. Morning stiffness with symmetrical involvement of joints is characteristic of RA. Osteoarthritis (Option B): In the case of osteoarthritis narrowing of joint space can be noticed which is not seen in the above image. Psoriatic Arthropathy (Option D): Similar presentation like rheumatoid arthropathy with associated skin and nail lesions. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Pages 67,78,87,88,91,92,637.

questions.question: Diagnosis of Gout is confirmed by which test?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Synovial Fluid Analysis Explanation: Gout Inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and tissues due to hyperuricemia Clinical Presentation: Acute Gouty Attack - Sudden onset of intense joint pain, typically affecting the big toe, but can also involve other joints such as the ankle, knee, wrist, or elbow Chronic Gout- Recurrent attacks of joint inflammation, development of tophi (deposits of urate crystals) in joints and soft tissues Diagnosis: Medical History- History of recurrent joint pain, sudden onset, and self-limiting nature of attacks. Physical Examination- Joint examination revealing signs of inflammation (redness, swelling, warmth) Synovial Fluid Analysis -Detection of monosodium urate crystals in synovial fluid aspirated from an affected joint Serum Uric Acid Level - Elevated serum uric acid levels (>6.8 mg/dL) may support the diagnosis, but levels can be normal during an acute attack. Treatment: Acute Attack - Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), colchicine, corticosteroids for pain relief and inflammation control Long-term Management - Lifestyle modifications (dietary changes, weight loss), medications to lower uric acid levels (allopurinol, febuxostat) to prevent further attacks. Serum Uric Acid Level (Option A): While elevated serum uric acid levels are often seen in individuals with gout, they are not sufficient to confirm the diagnosis on their own. Urine Uric Acid Levels (Option C): Urine uric acid levels are not typically used as a diagnostic test for gout. Although increased urinary excretion of uric acid may be observed in some cases of gout, it is not a specific or reliable marker for diagnosing the condition. X-Ray Changes (Option D): X-ray changes, such as the presence of joint erosions or bone damage, may occur in advanced stages of gout or if there have been recurrent episodes of inflammation over time. Reference: Gout

questions.question: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 20-year-old male patient who has been experiencing lower backache and morning stiffness for two years, along with bilateral heel pain for the past six months?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ankylosing spondylitis Explanation: Young male with lower backache and morning stiffness are suggestive of Ankylosing spondylitis. Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) / Marie Strumpell Disease Definition Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine) . Etiology Idiopathic; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS. Pathophysiology Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis). Clinical Features Musculoskeletal Symptoms: Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity) Limited spinal mobility Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia) Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees) Extra-articular Symptoms: Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia) Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD Clinical tests: Schober/ Modified Schober test (for lumbar spine) Gaenslen’s test Patrick/FABER test Figure of 4 test Pump handle test Diagnosis Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria: Clinical Criteria: Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest) Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes) Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex) Radiographic Criteria (X-ray): Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4) Radiological Features: Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint Squaring of vertebrae Bamboo spine Dagger sign MRI: Early detection of inflammation Laboratory Tests HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases) ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal Treatment Non-Pharmacological: Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises) Patient education on disease and exercise importance Pharmacological: NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness) TNF inhibitors/IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab) Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis) Corticosteroids (short-term flare control) Surgical: Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement) Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures) Complications Spinal fractures (minimal trauma) Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects) Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk Incorrect Options: Tuberculosis of the spine (Option A): Tuberculosis of the spine also known as Pott's disease, is a potential differential diagnosis, particularly in regions where tuberculosis is endemic. However, in this case, the patient's age, chronicity of symptoms, and the absence of constitutional symptoms such as weight loss and night sweats make ankylosing spondylitis more likely. Disc prolapse (Option C): Disc prolapse can cause lower back pain and radicular symptoms radiating down the leg due to nerve root compression. However, the presence of morning stiffness and bilateral heel pain in this patient suggests an inflammatory condition such as ankylosing spondylitis rather than a disc prolapse. Mechanical Pain (Option D): Mechanical pain resulting from musculoskeletal strain or injury, can certainly cause lower back pain. However, the chronicity of symptoms, morning stiffness, and the involvement of sacroiliac joints and heels make ankylosing

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Osteoarthritis Explanation: Involvement of PIP and DIP joint with sparing of MCP and wrist joints is suggestive of Osteoarthritis. Joint involvement in Arthritic diseases: Disease Joint involved & characteristics Joint spared Osteoarthritis Proximal and Distal interphalangeal joints (PIP and DIP), 1st Carpometacarpal joint, Hip and knee Asymmetrical involvement Wrist and Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints Rheumatoid arthritis Metacarpophalangeal joint (MCP) - most commonly involved Symmetrical involvement seen Distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) and 1st carpometacarpal (CMP) joint Psoriatic arthritis Proximal and Distal interphalangeal joints (PIP and DIP) Pencil-in-cup, telescoping of digits, arthritis mutilans Skin and nail involvement + Ray pattern distribution of joints seen Pseudogout (Option D): Usually large joints of elderly people are affected, most commonly Knee is involved. questions.question: Which joints are affected in a condition where the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are involved, while the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and wrist are spared?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Osteoarthritis Explanation: OA typically affects the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, especially in the hands. It often spares the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and wrists , making it characteristic of OA in the hands. Osteoarthritis (OA): It is the most common form of arthritis in the world. It mainly affects the hips, knees, spine, hands and feet. Clinical manifestations Symptoms: Pain (Nature and severity are variable) Joint stiffness (short-lasting stiffness after a period of inactivity) Fatigue Sleep disturbance Reduced functional ability and activities Signs: Tenderness of the joint Bony swelling Reduced range of movement with pain at the end of the range Crepitus on movement of the joint Weakness and wasting of muscles around the joint Signs of inflammation (mild) In severe cases - deformity and instability Varus deformity and fixed flexion deformity of the knee Varus deformity Commonly affected joints in the hand: Distal interphalangeal joints (DIPs) and the thumb base Classical findings in hand: Heberden’s nodes (posterolateral swellings of DIP joints) Bouchard’s nodes (posterolateral swellings of PIP joints) Squaring at the base of the thumb (first CMC joints) Kashin Beck disease : An extremely rare polyarticular form of OA. Seen in the people of Northern China and Eastern Siberia. Symptoms: Joint pain Polyarticular swelling Deformity from childhood Short stature X-ray: Distorted epiphyses and tubular long bones. Rheumatoid Arthritis (Option B) : Affects MCP joints and wrists symmetrically, not typically sparing them. Psoriasis (Option C) : Psoriatic arthritis can affect DIP joints but often involves other joints, including MCP joints. Hyperparathyroidism (Option D) : Causes bone changes but does not specifically affect DIP and PIP joints in the same pattern as OA.

questions.question: Diagnosis of Gout is confirmed by which test?
questions.explanation: considered the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis of gout. Gout is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints, leading to inflammation and symptoms. Synovial fluid analysis involves aspirating fluid from an affected joint and examining it under a microscope . The presence of needle-shaped urate crystals in the synovial fluid confirms the diagnosis of gout. Incorrect Options: Option A - Serum Uric Acid Level: While elevated serum uric acid levels are often seen in individuals with gout, they are not sufficient to confirm the diagnosis on their own. Many people with elevated serum uric acid levels do not develop gout, and some individuals with gout may have normal or only slightly elevated levels of uric acid. Therefore, serum uric acid levels alone are not definitive for diagnosing gout. Option C - Urine Uric Acid Levels: Urine uric acid levels are not typically used as a diagnostic test for gout. Although increased urinary excretion of uric acid may be observed in some cases of gout, it is not a specific or reliable marker for diagnosing the condition. Option D - X-Ray Changes: X-ray changes, such as the presence of joint erosions or bone damage, may occur in advanced stages of gout or if there have been recurrent episodes of inflammation over time. However, X-ray findings alone are not sufficient to establish a definitive diagnosis of gout, as they are not specific to the condition and can be seen in other joint disorders. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following statement about septic arthritis is true

options.A: Staph aureus is most common organism in adults
options.B: Incision and drainage done after culture of aspirate and antibiotic for 24 hours
options.C: Kocher’s criteria is used to differentiate from transient synovitis
options.D: Widening of joint space is seen

questions.explanation: True - Incision and drainage should be performed after obtaining a culture of the joint aspirate and initiating antibiotic therapy for at least 24 hours. This statement is correct as it is essential to identify the causative organism and initiate appropriate antibiotic treatment before performing surgical drainage. Incorrect Options: Option A - Staph aureus is most common organism in adults: False - Staph aureus is the most common organism in young children. This statement is incorrect as Staphylococcus aureus is a common causative organism in septic arthritis, especially in children. Option C - Kocher’s criteria is used to differentiate from transient synovitis: False - Kocher's criteria are not used to differentiate septic arthritis from transient synovitis. This statement is incorrect. Kocher's criteria are used to assess the likelihood of septic arthritis in children with an acutely painful hip, based on factors such as fever, inability to bear weight, elevated white blood cell count, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. It helps in determining the need for further diagnostic evaluation and treatment. Option D - Widening of joint space is seen: False - Widening of the joint space is not typically seen in septic arthritis. This statement is incorrect. In septic arthritis, joint space narrowing is more commonly observed due to the accumulation of inflammatory fluid and destruction of articular structures. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: How to manage a patient of Rheumatoid arthritis with deformity?
questions.explanation: Infliximab helps stop further structural deformity . The treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) involves both acute management of active disease and long-term management to control symptoms and prevent joint damage. Treatment of RA: Acute Stage Treatment: Corticosteroids: In the acute stage of RA with positive classical signs, corticosteroids may be prescribed temporarily for 1 to 2 weeks to reduce inflammation and pain. Lab Investigations: Anti-CCP (Anti-Cyclic Citrullinated Peptide): This test is considered the best investigation for RA, as it can be positive in the early stages and has prognostic importance. Rheumatoid Factor (RF): RF is positive in about 60% of RA cases but may also be positive in other conditions such as cryoglobulinemia, Parvo 19 infection, and hepatitis C. Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs): Hydroxychloroquine (HCQ): Used to treat mild RA, but may cause ocular side effects such as bull's eye-like maculopathy or hemeralopia. Sulfasalazine: Another DMARD option for RA treatment. Methotrexate: Considered the best DMARD for RA, typically administered at a dose of 7.5mg once a week. Regular monitoring of white blood cell (WBC) count is necessary to check for bone marrow suppression. Leflunomide: An alternative DMARD option for RA treatment, although less commonly used. Incorrect Options: Option A - Steroids: Steroids may be used as part of the treatment plan in RA to provide short-term relief of symptoms and manage acute flares. However, long-term use of steroids is generally not recommended due to their side effects, and they are not the primary treatment option for managing deformities in RA. Option B - Methotrexate with steroids: Using MTX with steroids, which can be a combination used in certain cases, especially for short-term symptom control or during a disease flare. However, the long-term management of deformities in RA usually involves the use of DMARDs rather than relying solely on steroids. Option D - Steroids only after NSAlDs fail: Using steroids only after NSAIDs (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) fail. While NSAIDs can help manage pain and inflammation in RA, they are not sufficient for controlling the disease or managing deformities. DMARDs, including MTX and biologic agents, are the mainstay of treatment for RA and are typically initiated early in the disease course. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which joints are affected in a condition where the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are involved, while the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and wrist are spared?
questions.explanation: the distal interphalangeal (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints of the hands. It typically spares the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and the wrist . The characteristic involvement of DIP and PIP joints with sparing of MCP and wrist joints is a typical feature of osteoarthritis. Incorrect Options: Option B - Rheumatoid Arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis typically involves multiple joints, including MCP and wrist joints, and may result in deformities. Option C - Psoriasis: Psoriatic arthritis can involve DIP, PIP, and MCP joints, along with skin and nail changes. Option D - Hyperparathyroidism: Hyperparathyroidism does not specifically affect DIP, PIP, MCP, or wrist joints. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following is the most specific for ankylosing spondylitis?

options.B: Costovertebral and costosternal ankylosis may cause restrictive lung disease

questions.explanation: Costovertebral and costosternal ankylosis may cause restrictive lung disease. The Costovertebral and costosternal ankylosis may cause restrictive lung disease. Trouble breathing as the upper body curves forward and the chest wall stiffens. Severe ankylosing spondylitis can also cause scarring of the lungs (pulmonary fibrosis) and an increased risk of lung infection . Incorrect Options: Option A - HLA B37: This is incorrect as HLA B 27 is a genetic marker that is strongly associated with an increased risk of developing ankylosing spondylitis. Option C - More common in Females: This option is incorrect as It is more common in More common in males. Option D - Vertebral Expansion: This option is incorrect as there is vertebral fusion. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the most common form of arthritis?
questions.explanation: degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown and gradual loss of cartilage in the joints. Osteoarthritis primarily affects weight-bearing joints such as the knees, hips, and spine, as well as the hands and other joints. It is associated with joint pain, stiffness, swelling, and reduced range of motion. Osteoarthritis is typically age-related and can be influenced by factors such as joint overuse, joint trauma, obesity, and genetics. Incorrect Options: Option A - Rheumatoid Arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is an autoimmune disease in which the immune system mistakenly attacks the synovium (the lining of the joints). It causes chronic inflammation, leading to joint pain, swelling, stiffness, and potentially joint deformities. Rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by the symmetrical involvement of multiple joints, typically affecting the small joints of the hands and feet. It is more common in women than men and can also affect other organs in the body. While rheumatoid arthritis is a significant form of arthritis, it is not as prevalent as osteoarthritis. Option B - Psoriatic Arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis is a type of inflammatory arthritis that occurs in some individuals with psoriasis, a chronic skin condition characterized by red, scaly patches on the skin. Psoriatic arthritis can cause joint pain, swelling, stiffness, and tenderness. It typically affects the joints of the fingers and toes but can also involve larger joints such as the knees, hips, and spine. Psoriatic arthritis is less common than osteoarthritis, but its association with psoriasis makes it an important consideration in patients with both skin and joint symptoms. Option C - Seronegative Arthritis: Seronegative arthritis is a term used to describe a group of inflammatory arthritis conditions that do not show certain specific antibodies, such as rheumatoid factor or anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies, in the blood. Some examples of seronegative arthritis conditions include ankylosing spondylitis, reactive arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and enteropathic arthritis. These conditions share common features of inflammatory joint involvement, but they may also have extra-articular manifestations. While seronegative arthritis conditions can cause significant joint inflammation, they are less prevalent than osteoarthritis. Reference: Prepladder Notes
